comments:

following NPE when restarting on existing self-hosting workspace.

As a result, some PDE containers got reported as unbound once IDE went up.

Severity	Description	Resource	In Folder	Location
	Creation Time
2	Unbound classpath container: 'org.eclipse.pde.core.requiredPlugins' in 
project org.eclipse.ant.core.	org.eclipse.ant.core			March 
24, 2004 10:43:40 AM

Raising severity, as this one is a recurrent issue with PDE container which 
isn't reliable.

Subsequent restart attempts failed in the same way. Basically, I cannot work on 
this build.

The problem here is that the workspace seems to contain a plug-in with a 
manifest.mf that lacks the Bundle-SymbolicName OSGi header.

In this new piece of code for resolving plug-ins, we don't check for null if 
this header is not present, and hence the NPE.  We do a null check now.

However, as per last week's arch call, with the ongoing changes in the runtime 
and Update, we cannot guarantee that you can launch a new Eclipse on a 
workspace created that contains plug-ins from an older 3.0 Eclipse and expect 
things to work.  Of course, you shouldn't see things blow up like you did and 
we'll make sure this won't happen, but compilation errors and/or other 
symptoms might occur, depending on your workspace setup and what plug-ins you 
have enabled on the Target Platform page.

This really does/should not undermine the robustness of classpath containers, 
as it has nothing do with them.  It has to do with the fact that PDE can 
possibly choke on plug-ins with outdated manifest.mf, and the classpath 
container can fail to initialize as a result.  This is all transient because 
the runtime will stabilize soon enough.  In the meantime, PDE is taking the 
hit for it.

Got patch from Wassim. It solved my problem, I am happy again.

I had various flavors of PDE container not properly functionning over the past 
weeks, and resulting in sometimes unbound containers, which would usually go 
away after a few exit/restart actions. But these seem to be gone, except for 
this new(?) present bug. On the surface, the end problem for me was an unbound 
PDE container, which explains my 'naive' reaction (but how could I tell?).

As for issues with reopening old workspaces, my understanding was that your 
contract is that you may not open old workspaces, but recent ones ok. My 
offending workspace got opened ok with 20030423 build, so I presume it still is 
a recent one (it shouldn't matter when it got created, if you did upgrade it 
gradually when opening with intermediate SDKs).
Also I had tried to reimport all plugins over old ones, and it still did not do 
the trick.

BTW, I spoke too fast, I have more NPEs now, and still instances of unbound PDE 
container.

Philippe, for now, please manually delete all the projects that you usually 
import from your workspace, and then import.  I will fix these two NPEs, but 
they are all related to the same problem.

This stack trace is not that big.  Philippe scares easy :-)

Added more paranoid code to not blow up when a proper bundle description 
cannot be created.  

1. Now, if the bundle manifest is missing the right header or 
an empty header, PDE does not create an internal model for it.

2. Also added paranoid null checks all over the place when we're retrieving 
the id/imports of the bundle.  Although these paticular checks should be 
unncessary due to 1., it does not hurt to be this paranoid in today's changing 
world.

>As for issues with reopening old workspaces, my understanding was that your 
>contract is that you may not open old workspaces, but recent ones ok.
In this day and age, an old workspace might be referring to one containing 
plug-ins from yesterday's build.

I'll mark this one as fixed, but it is hard to verify since I can't reproduce 
the problem and I don't know what the offending projects are or where they are 
coming from.  In any event, as long as they get deleted from the workspace, 
things should go back to normal.
